data.text: So a lot of studies have been done on this (trail nutrition), particularly in the context of thru hikers. Think 5-6 months on trail in one shot. One in particular stood out. The question was whether a crap diet or a super healthy diet would change the outcome of a group of I believe 20 Appalachian Trail thru hikers in terms of changes to their physical health and fitness at the end. The answer, surprisingly was no, with a slight edge actually going to the unhealthy diet. Basically, the conclusion they came to was that the quantity of calories was far more important than the quality of calorie. When you’re burning 5K-8K calories a day (typical day on the AT hiking 20+ miles) it’s almost impossible to match with your intake no matter what. Sure, you may FEEL better if you’re eating well and not just pounding snickers into your face, but your health itself won’t be any different because at the end of the day, you’re still most likely burning thousands more calories than you’re taking in regardless of the source. Far more important is how you eat off trail in your normal day to day life. Now, all that said, protein and fat is important for two purposes: protein will help you recover and is the most satiating of the macronutrients, and fat will give you a more slow burning consistent source of energy than carbohydrates. Carbs have their place though. When I’m on extended legs on trail, I basically focus on fats and carbs throughout the day, usually in the form of nutty trail mix and chocolate. Then I finish the day with a meal high in protein and fat. Mostly though I’m just trying to get as many calories in me as possible. But that’s not really out of a sense of wanting to eat well for my nutrition so much as the way it makes me feel. TL;DR eat whatever you want on trail it pretty much doesn’t matter and won’t effect your health in a meaningful way.

data.text: There's a few options for what might be happening when you hit the wall, but one of the more likely nutrition related ones is that you've run out of muscle glycogen. You can try to avoid this in 2 ways - go easier, so muscle gylcogen isn't your primary energy source and/or ensure you're eating to maximise its replenishment (~200kcal/hr of low fat mostly complex carbs - every hour, don't miss any). When I start a tour or do a short weekend trip, I start out eating a mini malt loaf every 30mins. After a few days my body doesn't need that level of strictness in refueling anymore and I swap to stopping to eat when I'm hungry but it definitely helps whilst it's re-adapting. Protein is much less of an issue for ultra endurance activities. You want some but I wouldn't worry about supplementing. Fat is a much better way to get calories in, just be aware that it will slow down the digestion / absorbtion process and if you eat high fat food whilst riding you might not feel great! (Unless you've adapted to use fat as your primary energy source, which is a whole other topic...)
data.author: Helen Colson

data.text: exactly this. Chris, on trail I’m basically consuming nothing but carbs and fat at a pretty steady pace all day. Keeps me level and energized. Then a big meal of higher protein content and fats. The biggest things I’m trying to do throughout the day is just get as many calories as possible. So super calorie dense foods are friends. Nuts and nut butter in particular, but also other fats for the most part. Since a gram of fat is worth 9 calories, while a gram of protein or carbohydrates is worth 4, you get over twice the bang for your buck carrying fatty foods rather than worrying about your protein intake. To be honest, the biggest problem I’ve had on trail nutrition wise is getting enough fiber, since I’m getting very few fresh veggies. If you want to bring any kind of supplement, a fiber supplement would be a much better use of pack space and weight than protein powder.

data.text:
Like many have said, increasing protein won't prevent bonking. I used to borderline bonk often, here's what works for me, I think it's the same for the majority but it may differ for others... Eat small bits (I don't want a gut bomb mid ride), eat often with a focus on replenishing carbs (I usually go for high carb bars), at least 1 bottle with electrolytes (IE: Nuun), bring some gel packs just in case, a chocolate bar for a treat (attitude upper for me). End of the day, I fatten up the machine and eat whatever I want & fuel up for the next day! Supplements, I like Hammer Nutrition's, they work for me and my gut. GCN has some good diet tips for big rides/trips, Bikepacking.com, IE; https://bikepacking.com/plan/do-it-yourself-rocket-fuel-for-bikepacking/
